message_1: A sample of a radioactive isotope starts with an activity of 1000 Bq. After 45 minutes, the activity drops to 250 Bq. Calculate the half-life of the radioactive isotope.
message_2:
To calculate the half-life of the radioactive isotope, we can use the decay formula:

N(t) = N0 * (1/2)^(t/T)

where:
N(t) is the activity at time t
N0 is the initial activity
t is the time elapsed (in this case, 45 minutes)
T is the half-life of the isotope

We are given:
N0 = 1000 Bq
N(t) = 250 Bq
t = 45 minutes

We need to find T (the half-life). We can rearrange the formula to solve for T:

T = t * (log(1/2) / log(N(t)/N0))

Plugging in the given values:

T = 45 * (log(1/2) / log(250/1000))
T = 45 * (log(1/2) / log(1/4))

Using a calculator to find the logarithms:

T = 45 * (-0.3010 / -0.6021)
T ≈ 45 * 0.5

T ≈ 22.5 minutes

The half-life of the radioactive isotope is approximately 22.5 minutes.
